review.title: Epistemic Protocols for Distributed Gossiping
review.abstract: Gossip protocols aim at arriving, by means of point-to-point or group communications, at a situation in which all the agents know each other's secrets. We consider distributed gossip protocols which are expressed by means of epistemic logic. We provide an operational semantics of such protocols and set up an appropriate framework to argue about their correctness. Then we analyze specific protocols for complete graphs and for directed rings.

We look at distributed gossip protocols expressed by epistemic logic. We provide a functional derivation of such protocols and provide a suitable framework for their complete analysis.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The problem is to find a sequence of calls that spread all the secrets between the agents in the group. It triggered a large literature in the 1970s and 1980s [18, 4, 9, 5, 17], which typically focused on the finding - in the above and other variants of the problem - that the minimum number of calls allowed the dissemination of all the secrets in the group. This number was proved to be 2n − 4, where n, the number of agents, is at least 4.The above literature assumes a centralized perspective on the gossip problem.

sections.heading: 2 Gossip protocols
sections.text: We will first introduce the syntax and semantics of gossip protocols.

sections.heading: 2.1 Syntax
sections.text: We loosely use the syntax of the language CSP (Communicating Sequential Processes) of [11], which augments the guarded command language of [6] with fragmented parallel composition and commands for synchronous communication. CSP was realized in the distributed programming language OCCAM (see INMOS [12]). The main difference is that we use epistemic formulas and primitive communication calls that do not require synchronization. Moreover, the syntax of our distributed programs is very limited. In order to define gossip logs, we introduce calls and epistemic guards in return. Throughout the escore essay, we assume a fixed limited group A of at least three agents. We assume that each agent holds exactly one secret and that there is a bijection between the group of agents and the group of secrets. We use P to denote the set of secrets (for propositions). Furthermore, it is assumed that any secret containing the identifying agents belongs to the secret.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: The aim of this work was to introduce distributed gossip protocols, create a formal framework for thinking about them, and illustrate them through an analysis of selected protocols. Our results open several avenues for further research. First, our correctness arguments were given in plain English with occasional references to epistemic tautologies, but it should be possible to formalize them in a tailored epistemic logic. Such a logic should have a protocol-independent component consisting of the usual S5 axioms and a protocol-dependent component that provides axioms that depend on the mode of communication and the protocol in question. An example of such an axiom is the formula KiFi-1 that we use when thinking about the reasoning on the protocol.
